questions.text: A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a motor vehicle collision. On arrival, he is unconscious and unresponsive to painful stimuli. His pulse is 120/min, respirations are 10/min, and his blood pressure is 88/60 mm Hg. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun, and intubation is attempted without success. Pulse oximetry on 20 L/min of oxygen via bag-mask shows an oxygen saturation of 78%. The most appropriate next step in the management involves passing a tube through an incision in which of the following structures?

choices.text: Prevertebral layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Incision of the buccopharyngeal fascia, which envelops the superior constrictor muscle of the posterior pharynx, is not part of the procedure to establish an emergency surgical airway that this patient requires.

B) CORRECT:

In emergency situations where a patient cannot be effectively ventilated by the conventional bag and mask ventilation or endotracheal intubation, a cricothyroidotomy is the surgical procedure of choice to restore oxygenation. A cricothyroidotomy is performed by vertically incising the skin (superficial cervical fascia, investing layer of deep cervical fascia, and pretracheal fascia) and then horizontally incising the cricothyroid membrane.
Image Description:

Larynx (ventral view):

The thyroid cartilage (top) and the cricoid cartilage (bottom) are cleary visible. Above the larynx is the hyoid bone, which is connected to the thyroid cartilage through the thyrohyoid membrane.

C) INCORRECT:

The annular ligaments of the trachea, which extend between the tracheal rings and hold the C-shaped rings of cartilage together, do not require an incision to establish an airway in this patient. Incision of an annular ligament (along with a tracheal ring) is done in tracheostomy, a procedure that is typically performed in elective or semi-elective situations where long-term mechanical ventilation is required or when acute upper airway obstruction occurs. This patient is in an emergency situation that requires immediate restoration of the airway and ventilation, for which tracheostomy is not the procedure of choice.

D) INCORRECT:

Incision of the cricotracheal ligament, which connects the cricoid cartilage to the first tracheal ring, is not part of the procedure to establish an emergency surgical airway that this patient requires.

E) INCORRECT:

Incision of the prevertebral layer of deep cervical fascia, which runs posterior to the trachea, is not part of the procedure to establish an emergency surgical airway that this patient requires.
Image Description:

Transverse section of the neck at the level of C7

The investing layer is located below the platysma and covers the sternocleidomastoid muscle as well as the trapezius muscle.
The pretracheal layer covers the infrahyoid muscles and attaches to the carotid sheath.
The prevertebral fascia surrounds the deep muscles of the neck, the brachial plexus, the sympathetic trunk, the subclavian artery and the phrenic nerve (not all depicted in this illustration).
The visceral fascia covers the organs of the neck.
questions.hint: Intubation has failed in this increasingly hypoxemic patient. The next step requires establishing a surgical airway.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man comes to the physician because of a change in his voice. His wife says his voice has progressively become higher pitched, and he has had a 5.4-kg (11.9-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Direct laryngoscopy shows an irregular, nodular glottic mass. A biopsy specimen of the mass shows poorly differentiated squamous cells with nuclear atypia, hyperkeratosis, and disruption of the basement membrane. Involvement of a muscle derived from which of the following pharyngeal arches is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The 6th pharyngeal arch gives rise to the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, with the exception of the cricothyroid muscle. These muscles are responsible for the opening and closing of the glottis, the relaxation of the vocal cords that allows pitch lowering, and fine adjustments to the vocal cords, which are important for phonation. This patient's increased pitch in voice is most likely due to cricothyroid muscle involvement, which is derived from a different pharyngeal arch.

B) INCORRECT:

The 2ndpharyngeal arch gives rise to the muscles of facial expression, stapedius (control of sound amplitude), stylohyoid (elevation of the hyoid), platysma (facial expression, jaw depression), and posterior belly of the digastric (jaw opening).

C) INCORRECT:

The 1st pharyngeal arch gives rise to the muscles of mastication, mylohyoid (elevation of the tongue, depression of the mandible), anterior belly of the digastric (jaw opening), tensor tympani (tensing of the tympanic membrane), and the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

D) INCORRECT:

The 3rd pharyngeal arch gives rise to the stylopharyngeus muscle, which elevates the larynx and pharynx during swallowing. Other structures that derive from the 3rd pharyngeal arch include the glossopharyngeal nerve and the greater horn of the hyoid bone.

E) CORRECT:

The 4th pharyngeal arch gives rise to the cricothyroid muscle as well as most muscles responsible for pharyngeal constriction. Contraction of the cricothyroid muscle causes vocal cord contraction, which controls pitch elevation. Involvement of the cricothyroid muscle should be suspected in any patient with changes in vocal pitch.
Image Description:

Clockwise from top left: nerve, skeletal structure, muscle, and artery derivatives of the pharyngeal arches.
questions.hint: Laryngeal carcinoma has caused this patient's voice to become high-pitched. The pitch of the voice is heightened by contraction of the vocal cords. This function is carried out by the cricothyroid muscle.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. During the last 6 months, he has had recurring pneumonia after undergoing a surgical operation. He reports that, when food has gone down his windpipe, he has not automatically coughed. Examination shows normal voluntary coughing, but an impaired cough reflex. The nerve responsible for this patient's symptoms is most likely damaged at which of the following anatomical sites?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Through the infratemporal fossa runs the mandibular nerve (CN V3), the third branch of the trigeminal nerve. Injury to CN V3 can lead to weakness of the mastication muscles as well as hyperesthesias of the chin, lower lip, and inside of the cheek. However, this nerve is not responsible for the absent laryngeal cough reflex seen in this patient, and the internal laryngeal nerve does not pass through the infratemporal fossa.

B) INCORRECT:

Through the foramen magnum travels the accessory nerve (CN XI), which innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Injury to CN XI would result in weakness of head-turning (contralateral side) and shoulder elevation (ipsilateral side). This nerve is not responsible for the absent laryngeal cough reflex seen in this patient, and the internal laryngeal nerve does not pass through the foramen magnum.

C) INCORRECT:

Under the aortic arch travels the left recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (CN X). Recurrent laryngeal nerve dysfunction can lead to hoarseness or dyspnea (due to paralysis of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle, which opens the vocal cords). However, this nerve is not responsible for the absent laryngeal cough reflex seen in this patient, and the internal laryngeal nerve does not pass through the aortic arch.

D) CORRECT:

The superior laryngeal nerve divides into an internal and external branch beneath the internal carotid artery. The internal laryngeal nerve runs directly beneath the mucosa of the piriform recess, along with the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and is distributed to the mucous membrane of the larynx. The internal laryngeal nerve can be injured during surgery (e.g., thyroidectomy) or damaged by food items (e.g., a fishbone) being trapped in the piriform fossa. Damage to this nerve classically manifests with an impaired cough reflex, which increases the risk for recurrent aspiration pneumonia.

E) INCORRECT:

Through the parotid gland runs the facial nerve (CN VII), which is commonly injured during parotid resections or oncologic procedures (e.g., vestibular schwannoma surgery). Injury to CN VII can lead to the ipsilateral loss of facial expression, impaired function of the submandibular, sublingual, and lacrimal glands, hyperacusis, and impaired taste perception of the anterior â…” of the tongue. However, this nerve is not responsible for the absent laryngeal cough reflex seen in this patient, and the internal laryngeal nerve does not pass through the parotid gland.
questions.hint: An intact cough reflex depends primarily on afferent fibers of the internal laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve), which transmit sensations of the larynx above the vocal cords, and on efferent fibers of the vagus, phrenic, and spinal motor nerves. This patient is able to cough voluntarily (indicating an intact efferent pathway) but has an impaired cough reflex (indicating a defect in the afferent pathway).

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of worsening painful swallowing, hoarseness, and bilateral otalgia. He has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss during this period. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Laryngoscopic examination shows an abnormal mass located on the right true vocal cord. Immunohistochemistry of the mass shows expression of HPV-16 DNA. This neoplasm most likely derived from which of the following types of epithelial tissue?

choices.text: Simple squamous epithelium with type I and type II cells
Stratified squamous epithelium with submucosal glands
Simple cuboidal epithelium with club cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Simple squamous epithelium with type I and type II cells lines the alveolar sacs. Type I pneumocytes are large flat squamous cells that facilitate gas exchange, while type 2 pneumocytes are more cuboidal and produce surfactant. HPV is not associated with any malignancies of the alveolar epithelium.
Image Description:

The alveolar walls contain three cell types: type 1 pneumocytes, type 2 pneumocytes, and alveolar macrophages. Type 1 pneumocytes are thin, flat cells that form the alveolar structure and make up 95% of its surface. Type 2 pneumocytes are far smaller in size but more numerous (thus accounting for about 60% of alveolar cells but taking up only 5% of the surface space) and produce the surfactant, which covers the entire alveolar lumen to reduce surface tension. The alveoli are separated from each other by the interalveolar septum with elastic fibres and capillaries; interalveolar pores connect adjacent alveoli.

B) CORRECT:

The true vocal cords have stratified squamous epithelium and a submucosal layer with mucous and serous glands that help lubricate the cords. The stratified squamous epithelium of the vocal cords consists of 5â€“25 layers of non-keratinized cells. The basal layer of the epithelium contains cells that are nucleated and appear more columnar or cuboidal. The cells become increasingly polygonal and flattened toward the surface. The HPV virus exhibits tropism for squamous epithelium. HPV-16 and HPV-18 are high-risk subtypes of HPV, which are associated with a greater risk of dysplasia and squamous cell cancer, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Simple ciliated columnar epithelium lines the bronchioles as far as the terminal bronchioles. The true vocal cords have a different type of epithelium and HPV does not exhibit tropism towards columnar cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (Ladewig trichrome stain; 200x)

A bronchiole (with a prominent air-filled lumen) is visible at the center of the image. Its wall features ciliated simple columnar epithelium and circular bundles of smooth muscle. Note that, unlike in a bronchus, there is no cartilage and glands. An arterial vessel is visible left of the bronchiole. Its entire lumen is filled with erythrocytes. The bronchiole and arterial vessel are surrounded by numerous air-filled alveoli.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium lines the mainstem bronchi and trachea, not the vocal cords. Moreover, HPV does not exhibit tropism towards columnar cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tracheal tissue (H&E stain; 300x magnification)

Tissue layers from top to bottom and from inside to outside:
â€“ Pseudostratified respiratory epithelium (green overlay) with occasional goblet cells (examples indicated by yellow overlays) and the basophilic nuclei of the basal cells that are arranged in a palisade-like pattern
â€“ Lamina propria with lots of collagen and elastic fibers, containing numerous seromucous tracheal glands (examples indicated by black arrows; excretory duct outlined in black) that are surrounded by smooth muscle (white dashed outline)
â€“ Incisions of several blood vessels
The characteristic tracheal cartilage rings cannot be seen in this image.

No pathologic features are noted.

E) INCORRECT:

Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium lines the trachea and main-stem bronchi. Depending on which part of the bronchus or trachea is examined on histopathology, cartilage may or may not be seen. The larynx does not have a pseudostratified columnar lining, and HPV does not exhibit tropism towards the columnar epithelium.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a tracheal biopsy sample (Ladewig trichrome stain; 50x magnification)

Tissue layers (from top to bottom and the outside in):

- Mediastinal connective tissue (white)
- Plate of hyaline cartilage (purple; hatched green overlay)
- Perichondrium (dark purple; black overlay)
- Smooth muscle (red; yellow overlay)
- Lamina propria with elastic fibers (red; red overlay)
- Respiratory epithelium (pink; green overlay)
- Tracheal lumen (white; hatched red overlay)

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

F) INCORRECT:

Simple cuboidal epithelium lines the respiratory bronchioles, which are part of the gas-exchanging respiratory zone of the lung. Club cells (Clara cells) are non-ciliated and interspersed with ciliated cuboidal epithelium. The true vocal cords do not have cuboidal epithelium and HPV is not associated with any malignancies of the respiratory bronchioles.
Image Description:

Overview of the different types of respiratory epithelium and components of the airway walls

The height of the epithelium decreases steadily from the trachea to the alveolar sacs and the distribution and prevalence of cell types and extracellular components changes throughout the airways.

(Note: The length and width of the bars indicate the approximate relative distribution and prevalence of the structures shown but do not represent absolute numbers or metric data.)
questions.hint: The presence of dysphagia, hoarseness, otalgia, and weight loss in an adult man without traditional risk factors (smoking, alcohol use) and an abnormal laryngeal mass is consistent with laryngeal carcinoma. HPV is associated with 20% of all laryngeal cancers in North America and Europe.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man undergoes parathyroidectomy for treatment-resistant hyperparathyroidism. The procedure is complicated by brisk bleeding from an artery that travels along the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. To stop the bleeding, the artery is ligated at its origin. Which of the following is most likely the origin of the artery that was injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The subclavian artery gives rise to the inferior thyroid artery via the thyrocervical trunk. The inferior thyroid artery pierces the lower pole of the thyroid gland and is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve. This patient has an injury of a vessel traveling with the superior laryngeal nerve rather than with the RLN.

B) INCORRECT:

The cervical portion of the internal carotid artery (ICA) has no branches and neither of the thyroid arteries arise from the ICA. As a result, ligation of the ICA would not affect this patient's bleeding. The first branches of the internal carotid arise in the petrous segment of the ICA. Before it terminates in the brain, the major branches include the ophthalmic artery and the superior hypophyseal artery, along with several smaller branches.

C) CORRECT:

The superior thyroid artery is a direct branch of the external carotid artery. After the carotid artery bifurcates in the carotid triangle, the superior thyroid artery arises as the first branch of the external carotid artery and supplies the cranial half of the thyroid gland before forming an anastomotic network with the inferior thyroid artery. The artery travels with the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve and pierces the thyroid gland at the superior pole. Therefore, bleeding from the superior thyroid artery would be controlled by ligating it at its origin from the external carotid artery.
Image Description:

Arterial supply: two paired arteries and a third inconsistent artery
- The superior thyroid artery (paired) originates from the external carotid artery and enters the thyroid gland at the superior pole.
- The inferior thyroid artery (paired) originates from the thyrocervical trunk (a branch of the subclavian artery) and enters the thyroid gland posteriorly.
- The solitary thyroidea ima artery (unpaired) is present in < 5% individuals. It may arise directly from the subclavian artery (as shown here) or from the aortic arch or the brachiocephalic artery. It enters the thyroid at the inferior border of the isthmus.

Venous drainage occurs via a venous plexus on the anterior surface of the thyroid (plexus thyroideus impar) that is drained by three paired veins:
- The superior thyroid veins drain into the internal jugular vein.
- The middle thyroid veins also drain into the internal jugular vein.
- The inferior thyroid veins drain into the brachiocephalic veins.

D) INCORRECT:

The thyrocervical trunk originates from the subclavian artery and gives rise to the inferior thyroid artery. The inferior thyroid artery pierces the lower pole of the thyroid gland and is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve. This patient has an injury of a vessel traveling with the superior laryngeal nerve rather than with the RLN.

E) INCORRECT:

The ascending pharyngeal artery arises from the external carotid artery and gives rise to a pharyngeal and neuromeningeal trunk. Branches of the ascending pharyngeal artery supply the pharyngeal constrictor muscles, tympanic cavity, and meninges but they do not travel along the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. Bleeding from the ascending pharyngeal artery or one of its branches would be unlikely during a parathyroidectomy.
questions.hint: The superior thyroid artery travels along the superior laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a 5-month history of hoarseness, exertional dyspnea, and fatigue. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His pulse is 98/min and irregular. His voice is coarse in quality. Physical examination shows a liver span of 16 cm and a soft diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hoarseness?

choices.text: Carcinoma arising from the mucosa of the larynx
Extrinsic impingement of the recurrent laryngeal nerve
Bacterial infection of the vocal folds
Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Laryngeal inflammation due to chemical irritant

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A squamous cell carcinoma arising from laryngeal mucosa can cause hoarseness, fatigue, dyspnea due to lung metastases and, rarely, hepatomegaly due to liver metastases. However, a laryngeal malignancy would not explain the atrial fibrillation and the diastolic murmur in this patient without risk factors for laryngeal malignancy such as smoking and alcohol consumption.

B) CORRECT:

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve winds around the arch of the aorta. Massive enlargement of the left atrium (and potentially also the pulmonary artery) in patients with mitral stenosis can compress this nerve resulting in hoarseness (Ortner syndrome). Other rare complications associated with massive left atrial enlargement are massive hemoptysis due to erosion of the bronchial arteries and esophageal compression (dysphagia megalatriensis).
Image Description:

Pleura and pericardium partially resected; removal of the thyroid gland reveals the course of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection of the vocal folds (laryngitis) with bacteria such as Moraxella catarrhalis, Hemophilus influenzae, and Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause hoarseness and fatigue, but the onset of symptoms would be acute, unlike in this patient, who has had symptoms for the past 5 months, and would likely include sore throat or a dry cough. Moreover, laryngitis would not cause exertional dyspnea, fatigue, hepatomegaly, or a diastolic murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with atrial fibrillation are at increased risk for a thromboembolic stroke, and a stroke in the region of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (lateral medullary syndrome) could cause hoarseness due to nucleus ambiguus infarction and dyspnea due to dorsal vagal nucleus infarction as well as fatigue. However, hoarseness and dyspnea would have been acute and preceded the onset of fatigue by weeks to months (post-stroke fatigue). Moreover, a PICA stroke would also cause other clinical features such as dysphagia, vertigo, nystagmus, ipsilateral ataxia, ipsilateral Horner syndrome, and decreased pain and temperature sensation in one side of the face and the contralateral half of the body.
Image Description:

Transverse section

Typically, the efferent cranial nuclei are located medially while the afferent nuclei are located more laterally.

E) INCORRECT:

Laryngeal inflammation from acidic gastric contents, which occurs in gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), can cause persistent hoarseness, but it would not cause exertional dyspnea, fatigue, hepatomegaly, or a diastolic murmur. Furthermore, this patient does not have other common features of GERD such as postprandial chest pain, belching, or dry cough.

F) INCORRECT:

Circulating acetylcholine receptor antibodies are seen in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG), which can cause fluctuating fatigue, hoarseness, stridor, and, rarely, dyspnea. The classic presentation of this condition includes diplopia and ptosis that worsen as the day progresses, neither of which have been reported by this patient. In addition, MG would not cause atrial fibrillation, a diastolic murmur, or hepatomegaly.
questions.hint: This patient's fatigue, exertional dyspnea, irregular heart rhythm, and hepatomegaly suggest atrial fibrillation and congestive heart failure (CHF). In this setting, the diastolic murmur at the apex is concerning for mitral stenosis, which commonly leads to left atrial dilation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman undergoes hemithyroidectomy for treatment of localized, well-differentiated papillary thyroid carcinoma. The lesion is removed with clear margins. However, during the surgery, a structure lying directly adjacent to the superior thyroid artery at the upper pole of the thyroid lobe is damaged. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Voice pitch limitation is caused by damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN), which occurs in up to 30% of thyroid dissections. The external branch of the SLN innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for lengthening, thinning, and stiffening the vocal cords and increases the pitch of phonation. The cricothyroid muscle is the only tensor of the vocal cord, and its denervation results in an inability to increase the pitch of the voice or produce explosive sounds as well as easy voice fatigability.
Image Description:

The thyroid gland is located in front of the trachea in the lower neck and consists of two lobes connected by an isthmus. A third pyramidal lobe extending from the isthmus is present in 50% of patients. This third lobe is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.

The parathyroid glands are located posterior to the thyroid gland; they may vary in number and location. The recurrent laryngeal nerves (RLN) branch off from the vagus nerve; the left RLN loops under the aortic arch, and the right RLN passes beneath the subclavian artery. Both RLNs are vulnerable to injury during thyroid surgery as they ascend to the larynx behind the thyroid gland. Unilateral RLN injury may result in hoarseness, and bilateral RLN injury may cause dyspnea and stridor.

B) INCORRECT:

Perioral paresthesia after thyroid surgery is a result of hypocalcemia secondary to hypoparathyroidism, usually due to unintentional removal of one or several of the parathyroid glands. Hypoparathyroidism is the most frequent complication of total or near-total thyroidectomy. However, the superior parathyroid glands are most commonly found inferior to the superior thyroid artery and the external branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve and are thus less likely to be injured in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Ineffective cough could result from unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury. This causes the affected vocal fold to rest in the paramedian or lateralized position. Coughing, which requires transient tight glottic closure, may then become ineffective. While unilateral RLN injury can occur during thyroid surgery, the nerve is unlikely to be damaged during ligation of the superior thyroid artery. Instead, the RLN is at risk during preparation of the inferior pole of the thyroid gland, as it runs close to the inferior thyroid artery.

D) INCORRECT:

Weakness of shoulder shrug can occur due to spinal accessory nerve injury (cranial nerve XI). The spinal accessory nerve runs through the posterior triangle of the neck and supplies the trapezius muscle, which is responsible for shoulder shrugging. However, injury to the spinal accessory nerve would not be expected during a hemithyroidectomy. The most common causes of spinal accessory nerve injury include biopsy of the cervical lymph nodes in the posterior triangle and radical neck dissection.

E) INCORRECT:

Difficulty swallowing and increased risk of aspiration can occur in bilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle. It also carries sensory input from the larynx below the vocal cords. The RLN can be injured during thyroid surgery because it passes close to the inferior thyroid artery on its ascent to the larynx. Unilateral damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is unlikely to cause difficulty swallowing.

F) INCORRECT:

Shortness of breath may be caused by bilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which can be injured during thyroid surgery because it passes lateral to the thyroid gland, adjacent to the inferior thyroid artery, on its ascent to the larynx. The RLN innervates the posterior cricoarytenoids, which are responsible for vocal cord abduction. In cases of bilateral RLN injury, the vocal cords are unable to abduct, which restricts air entry into the trachea and can lead to shortness of breath. Unilateral damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is unlikely to cause shortness of breath.
questions.hint: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve lies directly adjacent to the superior thyroid artery at the upper pole of the thyroid lobe. If the artery is ligated during surgery, it may be damaged.
